published_attributes.title: 💡 Intro
published_attributes.serialized_body:
As Product Designers, we design something to give form to a function - to solve a problem with a set of available resources.

Good design is solving a problem so that it seems like there was never a problem in the first place. Well designed interfaces, communication processes, or objects shouldn’t require too much effort from their users. Good design often makes you think: Gosh, I could have done that myself!

And yes, well-designed things are often a pleasure to look at or experience. Sometimes form precedes function.

published_attributes.title: 💡 Intro
published_attributes.serialized_body:
What you will learn in this chapter

  • Where to look for an inspiration
  • How to collect inspiration and prepare moodboards
  • How to prepare style-guides
  • Specific design states and how to prepare one
  • Tips for designing for a specific device
  • Tips on gathering feedback
  • Best practices for working in teams
  • Where to find design resources
  • Figma tips

Questions you should ask yourself before this stage

  • Do I have all the User Flows covered?
  • Do I understand all the Use Cases?
  • Do I have Brandbook/Brand Identity?
  • Do I have general Look&Feel? (Was it discussed with the client?)
  • Do I understand end users specifics? (ie. do I have to consider any special accessibility requirements?)

Which Stakeholders you will need at this stage

  • Client
  • Designer
  • QA
  • Developers
  • PM

published_attributes.title: 💡 Intro
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Tools that can help you at this stage

  • Figma/Sketch for turning your Wireframes into Visual Designs

For Interactive designs

If there is enough time, try to search for ready transitions between elements of your designed interface. This will highly increase experience of users, as animations in your project really does magic. To prepare such interactions you can use:

  • Principle - when there’s a need to animate interface elements, especially in a multi-screen project; the build-in transitions and element-based animations help to create quick and easy clickable prototypes. Principle is the go-to tool if:
    • you need to build a quick prototype to check if a UI solution works
    • you want to make sure the developer knows how to code the interaction
    • you want to enrich the experience by creating meaningful animations
    • you want to showcase your design on social media 
  • Figma / InVision Studio / Other design tools - you can also use Figma’s built in prototyping tools which should be enough for most use cases, but allow you to spice things up with features like Smart Animate.
  • Adobe After Effects - is a power workhorse, it can do almost everything related to animation. While versatile and powerful, After Effects lacks when it comes to working with Sketch files and you can’t test your interactions on a prototype. After Effects is the go-to tool if:
    • you need custom transitions or animation effects
    • you need to use perspective or other video effects
    • you want to animate icons and illustrations
  • Craft your own icons - if there is enough time, you can prepare your own icon set. We use Nucleo for our designs, but creating your own icons will add more individual feeling to application. Here’s a cool Webinar about Icon Design: Webinar: Icon Architecture

Figma / InVision Studio / Other design tools - you can also use Figma’s built in prototyping tools which should be enough for most use cases, but allow you to spice things up with features like Smart Animate.

Adobe After Effects - is a power workhorse, it can do almost everything related to animation.
While versatile and powerful, After Effects lacks when it comes to working with Sketch files and you can’t test your interactions on a prototype. After Effects is the go-to tool if:
you need custom transitions or animation effects
you need to use perspective or other video effects
you want to animate icons and illustrations

Craft your own icons - if there is enough time, you can prepare your own icon set. We use Nucleo for our designs, but creating your own icons will add more individual feeling to application. 

Here’s a cool Webinar about Icon Design:
Webinar: Icon Architecture

published_attributes.title: ✨ Inspirations - find accurate style for the project
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Remember, that inspiration process is really important during starting designing new project. Whole feeling of application/website depends which colours, fonts or photos you will use for that. Remember: Do not copy, just inspire!

You can find for inspiration here:

  • 👉 Awwwards
  • 👉 Dribbble
  • 👉 Behance
  • 👉 Designspiration
  • 👉 Pinterest
  • 👉 Designmadeingermany
  • 👉 Mobbin

published_attributes.title: 🧩 Preparing moodboards
published_attributes.serialized_body:
This step is really important for you and your client. There are situations, when you finish your design and Client is really happy - but not always. Great thing is to prepare a board with a lot of photos and pictures that will show your Client what you would like to do with his future app, what “feelings” your designs will evoke and finally, what he can expect. Thanks to this approach you will highly increase chances that Client would love your solutions and also he will see that you care of his feedback. Approx time: 4h

How to prepare Moodboards?

Use Boards by InVision for following reasons:

  1. Flexibility
  2. Predefined layouts
  3. Possibility to add images, fonts and attachments

or just keep everything in Figma

Moodboard example → Link

published_attributes.title: 🎨 Styleguides
published_attributes.serialized_body:
It’s good to explore at the very beginning of the project. Take your time, establish the look and feel of the app and then start creating the styleguide. During the whole visual design process you should update your styleguide to full version. Keep in mind it should be updated on a regular basis, otherwise you’ll need to dedicate some time after the entire UI phase is completed. Examples of Styleguides → Here, Here and Here

What a good Styleguide contain?

Colors Main colors and shade variations for each of them Inspirations → Here and Here

Typography Font family and type scale

Limit the number of typefaces and sizes you use in order to keep your designs simple. As a general rule of thumb, start with at most two fonts — one for your headers, and one for your bodies. Most of the time, you won’t need any more than that.

We highly recommend to use a free fonts. If you want use a paid version, check carefully the license. If using paid fonts, we charge clients. We can buy fonts for them and bill them - make sure client agrees before that happens.

Free fonts → Google Fonts Paid fonts → MyFonts and Typekit Font pairing → TypeWolf and FontPair

published_attributes.title: 🎨 Styleguides
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Component library Component-based thinking helps engineers. From an engineering perspective, components are like lego blocks that you can compose together.

Components represents states of the design, for example: Buttons (normal, hover, active, disabled) Inputs (empty, selected, typing, error, succes) Inspirations → Here and Here Grids and Spacings It’s important to establish a grid system that works for every use case. In the section on grids, include information on the number of columns and rows, margins, and example uses.

Examples → 8pt grid system and Bootstrap grid How to use it → Lear why grids are so powerful and how to use them.

blocks.text:
Component library
Component-based thinking helps engineers. From an engineering perspective, components are like lego blocks that you can compose together.

Components represents states of the design, for example:
Buttons (normal, hover, active, disabled)
Inputs (empty, selected, typing, error, succes)
Inspirations → Here and Here

Grids and Spacings
It’s important to establish a grid system that works for every use case. In the section on grids, include information on the number of columns and rows, margins, and example uses.

Examples → 8pt grid system and Bootstrap grid 
How to use it → Lear why grids are so powerful and how to use them.

published_attributes.title: 🔘 States of Design
published_attributes.serialized_body:
These states will repeat based on the page, user interaction, updated data, and pretty much any change of your application’s state. By thoughtfully designing for these changes, you can create a polished experience for users no matter which situation they find themselves in.

  • Nothing What happens before your component does anything? Maybe it’s the first time a user sees it. Maybe it’s not activated yet. Essentially, the component exists but hasn’t started.
  • Loading The dreaded state. In a perfect world, no one would ever see this; Alas, here we find ourselves. There are plenty of ways to keep your loading state subtle and unobtrusive.
  • None Your component has initialized, but it’s empty. No data. No Items. Now may be a good time to get the user to act (“Do this thing!”), or to reward them (“Good job, everything is taken care of”).
  • One You have some data. On an input, this may be after the first keystroke. In a list, it might be when you have one item (or one left).
  • Some This is usually what you think of first. What is the ideal state for this component? Your data is loaded, you have input, and the user is familiar with it.
  • Too many The user has overdone it in some way. Too many results (maybe you paginate them now), too many characters (maybe ellipses?), and so on.
  • Incorrect Something is not right about the component. An error has occurred.
  • Correct This item has had its needs satisfied
  • Done The user’s correct input has been received by the application. They don’t have to worry about it anymore.

Still not enough for you? Find out more here

blocks.text: These states will repeat based on the page, user interaction, updated data, and pretty much any change of your application’s state. By thoughtfully designing for these changes, you can create a polished experience for users no matter which situation they find themselves in.

Nothing
What happens before your component does anything? Maybe it’s the first time a user sees it. Maybe it’s not activated yet. Essentially, the component exists but hasn’t started.

Loading
The dreaded state. In a perfect world, no one would ever see this; Alas, here we find ourselves. There are plenty of ways to keep your loading state subtle and unobtrusive.

None
Your component has initialized, but it’s empty. No data. No Items. Now may be a good time to get the user to act (“Do this thing!”), or to reward them (“Good job, everything is taken care of”).

One
You have some data. On an input, this may be after the first keystroke. In a list, it might be when you have one item (or one left).

Some
This is usually what you think of first. What is the ideal state for this component? Your data is loaded, you have input, and the user is familiar with it.

Too many
The user has overdone it in some way. Too many results (maybe you paginate them now), too many characters (maybe ellipses?), and so on.

Incorrect
Something is not right about the component. An error has occurred.

Correct
This item has had its needs satisfied

Done
The user’s correct input has been received by the application. They don’t have to worry about it anymore.
Still not enough for you? Find out more here

published_attributes.title: 📱 Designing specifics for mobile native apps
published_attributes.serialized_body:
If you are starting with designing native apps, the best thing is to read official guidelines for Android (Material design) and for iOS (Human Interface Guidelines) operation systems.

  • Android Guidelines - Material Design Guidelines
  • Apple Guidelines - Human Interface Guidelines
  • Designing for Gestures Use most common gestures, to make application even more interactive. Remember, while using your phone there is no “hover effect” like in case of browsing websites. Try to provide most common and intuitive finger gestures, to areas where users expect that. Material Design Gestures Gestures for Apple Devices

blocks.text: If you are starting with designing native apps, the best thing is to read official guidelines for Android (Material design) and for iOS (Human Interface Guidelines) operation systems.
Android Guidelines - Material Design Guidelines
Apple Guidelines - Human Interface Guidelines

Designing for Gestures
Use most common gestures, to make application even more interactive. Remember, while using your phone there is no “hover effect” like in case of browsing websites. Try to provide most common and intuitive finger gestures, to areas where users expect that.
Material Design Gestures
Gestures for Apple Devices

draft_attributes.serialized_body:
If you are starting with designing native apps, the best thing is to read official guidelines for Android (Material design) and for iOS (Human Interface Guidelines) operation systems.

  • Android Guidelines - Material Design Guidelines
  • Apple Guidelines - Human Interface Guidelines
  • Designing for Gestures Use most common gestures, to make application even more interactive. Remember, while using your phone there is no “hover effect” like in case of browsing websites. Try to provide most common and intuitive finger gestures, to areas where users expect that. Material Design Gestures Gestures for Apple Devices

published_attributes.title: 💬 Gathering feedback
published_attributes.serialized_body:
From Teammates

Remember, if you have any troubles with your design you can always ask other designers for feedback. It’s also important to share your solutions with team before sharing with the Client. With this approach you can improve your designs, catch bugs or logic issues in your solutions or just read praises and collect thumb-ups.

  • Just go to #tradeguru-design, share link to your designs in Invision and ask there for some help, opinions or comments or
  • Go to your #team-design channel and do the same as above
  • Ask other designer for a review - quick face to face call through Slack or Hangouts
  • If you are not sure that we can spend more time preparing dedicated designs, ask your PM if we have enough resources / time / money to development such features
  • Ask your leader

From Client

Gathering feedback from Client is a key to successful project.

  • Ask for feedback you want to receive
  • Add designs to project and share link with Client. The best way is to always keep links to designs in InVision or Figma in project management tool, e.g. Jira (NOTE: Please avoid adding Client as a contributor to Invision projects)
  • Ask if he knows how Invision or Figma works or just guide him through the process of adding comments to designs (mentioning user’s name during adding comment will send an e-mail notification - recommended)
  • Answer to comments and mark them as resolved
  • If something is not clear to you or Client try to explain as long as everything is crystal clear to both sides
  • Preparing clickable designs (links between views) - that increases Client’s experience
  • Stay in-touch with Client on Slack - send him updated links to Invision or Figma, give him updates and what’s more important - ask him about the feelings and emotions that designs evokes
  • If you want you and your PM can setup a call with Client to present your designs - as sometimes you need to sell your vision or just tell a bigger picture of what is behind your designs

published_attributes.title: ✅ Best Practices - Do’s and Dont’s
published_attributes.serialized_body:
#1 Start every project with a brainstorm session

  • Debate and encourage wild ideas
  • Capture the ideas in a medium visible to the whole group
  • Number your ideas and go for quantity
  • Having a non-designer while brainstorming brings diversity to the table
  • Suspend judgement: no one is allowed to criticize

#2 Be sure to know your responsibilities and overall team hierarchy

  • Make sure you clearly understand your role and tasks you’re responsible for
  • Remember about the project timeline and task deadlines
  • When responsible for task distribution, be sure to balance skill sets and eliminate gaps

#3 When on design conflicts bring subject back to business objectives

  • When a conflict arises gather all arguments from the team and choose the solution which serves your product’s business objectives better
  • Support your ideas with real-life examples and surveys
  • Don’t let the aesthetics or personal preferences be your primary guide when on search for solutions
  • Be on the lookout not to reinvent the wheel: probably your problem was already solved somewhere

#4 Be a team player and work to deliver business objectives

  • Be responsive and helpful: if a team member asks you about an urgent feedback, give it a high priority
  • Solve conflicts and misunderstandings within the team quickly: personal conflicts have the tendency to escalate
  • Don’t take credit for the final design on your own
  • Don’t get too attached to your designs, your teammates solutions may be better than yours

Number your ideas and go for quantity
Having a non-designer while brainstorming brings diversity to the table
Suspend judgement: no one is allowed to criticize
#2 Be sure to know your responsibilities and overall team hierarchy

published_attributes.title: ✅ Best Practices - Do’s and Dont’s
published_attributes.serialized_body:
#5 Prepare your files properly

  • Good naming conventions; standardizing folder naming within Figma
  • Use text styles and layer styles
  • Create Components in Figma for repeating patterns
  • Use Frames and Pages in Figma
  • Don’t scatter around files: use one place for all project’s assets. Ideally on a shared folder
  • Be on the lookout for bad layer or file naming
  • Don’t leave your layers ungrouped and unnamed: your team member might need to pick-up from your file

#6 Give feedback and be open for feedback

  • Always ask for feedback on every step within your team; have regular design reviews
  • Before presenting work to the client be sure to get feedback from the whole design team on #tradeguru-design
  • Don’t be stubborn or deaf for constructive criticism - nobody grows without feedback

#7 Presenting and defending your ideas

  • Knowing why your design works is key to explain and defend it well
  • Do research on ideas you try to convince the client to
  • know the numbers behind your solutions
  • Don’t use jargon while presenting your work – the client doesn’t have to know what a persona or above-the-fold mean

#8 Embrace the culture of communication

  • Communicate clearly, early and often
  • It’s a good idea to have a live call with the client when presenting designs for the first time - this way you have the opportunity to answer all questions and avoid misunderstandings
  • Don’t be afraid to ask, remember: there are no stupid questions
  • Don’t assume your client knows how to use collaboration tools
  • Don’t leave designs of complicated processes without any comments

published_attributes.title: ❓ Q&A
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Desired outcomes after this stage

  • Moodboard, example here  and here
  • Styleguide, external example , internal example
  • Designs, example here
  • Perfectly scoring Checklist after this stage - check DWS Checklist Template

Questions your client may ask at this stage

Why designing in teams is better? Broader skillset & experience (complementary teams with unique skills like UX, visual or illustration); effective problem solving by instant incorrect assumption and bad solution verification; increased work efficiency by smart task distribution (certain designers work faster on certain tasks); increased chance of product success by greater idea-creation power and instant second opinion with full-context feedback

Why do I have to pay for fonts? Paid fonts are usually of higher quality and contain a broader range of styles and weights (giving more freedom in hierarchy design), additional glyphs and ligatures and a decent kerning table. A paid font also helps to build a more unique visual voice making it easier to stand out from the crowd. This seems to be of small importance, but keep in mind, that web and mobile products are in 95% based on typography. By using a quality font you are making sure your product design will also be of the highest quality.

Why I have to have custom icons, why can’t we just buy one? Icons and illustrations are not just about pretty pictures – they convey a message. By using custom made images you can be sure that they illustrate the concept as best as possible. Just like brands are using corporate colors and fonts, a unique visual style can help to differentiate from your competition and speak a consistent visual language.

I don’t work in Figma, how can I see the designs? We can provide you with a number of different file types to get you covered: from flattened PNGs, multi-layer PDFs to advanced documentation in form of a HTML file with all necessary informations for your developer. For feedback we use a tool called InVision or Figma which is a browser-based prototype with conversation-like commenting.

Where can I find some inspiration? The best source of inspiration would be Behance (behance.net) and Dribbble (dribbble.com).

What is a style guide and why do I need one? A style guide is a type of template containing colors, fonts and commonly used interface elements to standardize the look and feel of the whole product. It helps to keep a consistent visual style across all screens, devices and during the whole design process. It is especially needful on multi-designer projects where every team member is responsible for a different part of the product.

What kind of feedback you want me to give? Although we designers always try to deliver solutions that serve both the user and the business itself – you can try to check if the designs serve business objectives and fit the industry. Remember that esthetics are often a matter of personal taste, and your’s might not be the most universal one for your product’s potential users.

Styleguide, external example , internal example
Designs, example here

For feedback we use a tool called InVision or Figma which is a browser-based prototype with conversation-like commenting.

Where can I find some inspiration?
The best source of inspiration would be Behance (behance.net) and Dribbble (dribbble.com).

What is a style guide and why do I need one?
A style guide is a type of template containing colors, fonts and commonly used interface elements to standardize the look and feel of the whole product. It helps to keep a consistent visual style across all screens, devices and during the whole design process. It is especially needful on multi-designer projects where every team member is responsible for a different part of the product.

What kind of feedback you want me to give?
Although we designers always try to deliver solutions that serve both the user and the business itself – you can try to check if the designs serve business objectives and fit the industry. Remember that esthetics are often a matter of personal taste, and your’s might not be the most universal one for your product’s potential users.

published_attributes.title: ❓ Q&A
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Questions you should ask yourself after this stage

  • Do I have a Moodboard
  • Do I have a Styleguide?
  • Do I design for all target devices and design states?
  • Do I gather feedback from client and the team
  • Perfectly scoring Checklist after this stage - check DWS - Design Workflow Standards checklist
